author: LightFykki

text:
@SupraDarky Anything in a video game that is made for that game alone is Video Game Music, lyrics or not.

If it's made for outside, like a Band or artist, of a game, it's not Game Music.

(Good example: 
GTA series = None Music(Or barely.)
DDR remixes(Tons of them.) = VGM
author: Vordox

author: Fearmaster129

text: Note that I agree with the fact that it has that commercial sound (Yamaoka usually means real live rock instruments, drums etc.), I simply disagree with the fact that it shouldn't be considered video game music, for the reason I said above.
author: SupraDarky

text: I have to disagree. Unlike some other commercial songs used in video games like the vocal themes in Kingdom Hearts, all the vocal songs in the SH series were specifically composed and written for the games by Yamaoka. No other criterias should be needed for them to be considered game music. As you say, it probably comes from your traditionalist side.
author: SupraDarky

text: While i agree that it doesn't sound like video games music, I feel it still sounds good. And in the end that's what matters.

text: Now that Akira Yamaoka left the company, it might as well be over for this series. His direction and music was at least half of the games. Really sad because SH is my favorite survival horror series.
